wordpressPost.title: WTF is X-Frame-Options?
wordpressPost.content:
Hereâ€™s a fun way to waste an afternoon:

  1. You have a user flow that involves reading user docs: some gDocs, some YouTube videos, and some UI practice links of your own.
  2. Opening these in a new tab is annoying, right?
  3. So you move them into modals using iframes
  4. Everything works! ??
  5. Then, you give it to QAâ€¦
  6. 2 out of 8 links donâ€™t open for them.
  7. O.o

Every link opens a modal with an iframe. That part works. Two of the links â€“ a YouTube video and a UI practice widget â€“ never load.

You think it might be a slowness issue because you wait a few seconds and thereâ€™s no loading indicator. So you ask them to waitâ€¦ doesnâ€™t help. QA waits for many minutes but the two iframes stay blank.

o.O

You investigate. It still works for you. But QA is using Windows.

You find a Windows machine, do the Windows 10 forced update dance, and download the latest Chrome. Itâ€™s not a computer you use very often. The touchpad feels funny.

The two iframes, they donâ€™t load. Wut.

The console sheds a clue: Refused to display because it set X-Frame-Options to SAMEORIGIN.

What the hell is X-Frame-Options? Why does GoogleÂ only return results and StackOverflow questions from 2010, 2012, and 2013. Most of them still in PHP! Why have I not heard of this!?

X-Frame-Options: SAMEORIGIN is an HTTP header that guards websites against clickjacking attacks. It tells browsers, â€œYo, donâ€™t open this page in an iframeâ€.

YouTube sets the header for URLs that arenâ€™t embed links, which explains the single YT link that didnâ€™t work in my case. I was using embed links for all but one of them. ?

And our own practice-the-interface link?

Rails 4 sets X-Frame-Options: SAMEORIGIN for everything as a default security measure. I just never noticed before.

At least it was easy to fix â€“Â donâ€™t send the header. ğŸ˜€

But why did it work on my computer?

At first, I thought maybe itâ€™s because Chrome Mac and Chrome Windows behave differently. I tried on a coworkerâ€™s machine, and it didnâ€™t work. It stopped the iframes like itâ€™s supposed to.

Then I thought, â€œMaybe itâ€™s because Iâ€™m on localhost.â€ Nope, wasnâ€™t that.

Maybe it figures out swizec.ngrok.io points to my local machine? Waitâ€¦ the YouTube link worked, so it canâ€™t be that.

â€¦Why doesnâ€™t my computer protect me from clickjacking? This is not idealâ€¦

But hey, at least I know about X-Frame-Options now. That was fun. ?
